item.title: Mantis Overlords Ancient Aliens or Earthâ€™s Hidden Rulers?
item.description:
Mantis Overlords: Ancient Aliens or Earthâ€™s Hidden Rulers? ðŸ”—

Encounters Along the Musconetcong River ðŸ”—

This section focuses on reported sightings of Mantis beings along the Musconetcong River in New Jersey, starting around 2006. Key elements include the consistency of witness accounts, describing tall, insectoid figures accompanied by electronic malfunctions and a silent forest. Paul Jax’s sighting, where he made eye contact with a seven-foot-tall Mantis being, is highlighted. Joe Pari’s experience details telepathic contact, memory extraction, and paralysis, suggesting a hierarchical extraterrestrial structure with the Mantis beings in a leadership role. The Musconetcong River area is presented as a hotspot for these encounters.

Patterns in Abduction Testimonies ðŸ”—

This section explores the commonalities found in numerous alien abduction reports involving Mantis beings. It emphasizes the consistent descriptions of their physical appearance: triangular heads, large black eyes, and thin, insect-like bodies. The section also highlights the Mantis beings’ commanding presence and their role as supervisors of smaller gray aliens during abduction procedures. The Terry Lovelace case from Devilâ€™s Den State Park is mentioned as an example where gray aliens are seen working under the direction of Mantis beings. The Mantis beings are portrayed as cold, efficient, and in complete control, often communicating telepathically and overseeing medical procedures.

Ancient Evidence in Stone ðŸ”—

This section delves into potential historical evidence suggesting the presence of Mantis-like figures in ancient art and mythology. It mentions a petroglyph in Tamura, Iran, depicting a humanoid figure with mantis-like features, dating back thousands of years. The rock art of the San people (Khoisan) in Africa, which includes mantis-headed figures often associated with creator gods, is also discussed. The section emphasizes the widespread nature of these depictions across different continents and cultures, from Mesopotamian and Egyptian texts to Native American legends, implying a long-standing global presence.

A Portal in New Jersey? ðŸ”—

This section explores the theory that certain geographic locations, like the Musconetcong River area, may act as interdimensional portals. It suggests that fault lines near the river could generate unusual electromagnetic fields, similar to NASA’s “X-points” or magnetic portals. The section proposes that these locations could serve as doorways for beings like the Mantis to enter our reality. Witnesses’ descriptions of time distortions, electronic interference, and sensory overload during Mantis encounters are linked to the potential presence of these portals.

What Are They After? ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential motives and purposes of the Mantis beings. It contrasts them with the typical image of curious extraterrestrial explorers, suggesting they have a specific agenda. Theories discussed include the possibility that they have guided human development from behind the scenes, influenced civilizations, or are conducting long-term genetic experiments. The idea of them harvesting knowledge and energy from humanity is also presented. The section emphasizes the consistent theme that the Mantis beings are not new to Earth.

The Overlords Among Us? ðŸ”—

This section concludes by addressing the credibility of abduction accounts and the implications of the Mantis phenomenon. It mentions the work of paranormal researchers, including Harvard psychiatrist Dr. John Mack, who have documented abduction cases and found them difficult to dismiss as mere delusions. The section raises the question of the Mantis beings’ true identity and purpose, suggesting they could be interdimensional travelers, ancient creators, or something else entirely. It emphasizes the chilling reality of the experience for those who have encountered them and suggests they have been present on Earth for millennia, hidden in shadows and recorded in ancient texts.

source: https://www.latest-ufo-sightings.net/2025/05/mantis-overlords-ancient-aliens-or-earths-hidden-rulers.html

item.title: List of ufologists
item.description:
List of Ufologists ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article provides a list of notable individuals identified as ufologists, defined as people who investigate the possibility of UFOs being linked to extraterrestrial aliens. The list is organized by country. The article also includes a maintenance template indicating that it relies excessively on primary sources and needs improvement with secondary or tertiary sources.

Argentina ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Argentina.

  • Juan Posadas (1912â€“1981): A Trotskyist theorist who combined Trotskyism with Ufology, creating a unique strain known as Posadism.
  • Fabio Zerpa (1928â€“2019): A parapsychologist and UFO researcher.

Australia ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Australia.

  • Ross Coulthart: A journalist and lawyer who interviewed UFO whistleblower David Grusch regarding alleged US governmental cover-ups of UFO recovery programs.

Brazil ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Brazil.

  • Ademar JosÃ© Gevaerd (1962â€“2022)

Canada ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Canada.

  • Paul Hellyer (1923â€“2021): A former Canadian Defense Minister.
  • Stanton Friedman (1934â€“2019): A U.S.-born Canadian ufologist and former nuclear physicist who conducted early research on the Roswell incident and MJ-12 documents.

Estonia ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Estonia.

  • JÃ¼ri Lina (b. 1949)
  • Igor Volke (1950-2024): A ufologist and researcher of environmental anomalies.

France ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from France.

  • Jacques Bergier (1912â€“1978): A writer and co-author of the bestseller The Morning of the Magicians.
  • RÃ©my Chauvin (1913â€“2009): A biologist and entomologist.
  • Robert Charroux (1909â€“1978): A writer who promoted the Ancient Astronauts theory.
  • AimÃ© Michel (1919â€“1992): A writer and ufologist.
  • Jacques VallÃ©e (b. 1939): A computer scientist and author, an important figure in UFO studies in both France and the United States, who promoted the extraterrestrial hypothesis and later the interdimensional hypothesis.

Indonesia ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Indonesia.

  • J. Salatun (1927â€“2012): A pioneer of UFO research in Indonesia.

Italy ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Italy.

  • Monsignor Corrado Balducci (1923â€“2008): A Roman Catholic theologian of the Vatican Curia and long-time exorcist for the Archdiocese of Rome.

Mexico ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Mexico.

  • Jaime Maussan (b. 1953): A Mexican journalist and ufologist.

Romania ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Romania.

  • Dan Apostol (1957â€“2013): A writer and researcher specializing in several domains.
  • Doru Davidovici (1945â€“1989): A fighter pilot and writer, author of the bestseller Lumi Galactice â€“ colegii mei din neÈ™tiut (“Galactic worlds â€“ my colleagues from the unknown”).
  • Ion Hobana (1931â€“2011): A science fiction writer, literary critic, and ufologist.

Spain ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Spain.

  • Iker JimÃ©nez Elizari (b. 1973): A journalist licensed in Sciences of the Information, known for his work on paranormal activity, Ufology, and other mysteries on the TV show Cuarto Milenio and its radio version Milenio 3, along with his wife Carmen Porter.

Switzerland ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from Switzerland.

  • Billy Meier (b. 1937)
  • Erich von DÃ¤niken (b. 1935): A controversial author known for his books examining possible extraterrestrial influences on early human culture.
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos (b. 1978): Known for his work on Ancient Aliens and alien memes.

United Kingdom ðŸ”—

This section lists ufologists from the United Kingdom.

  • Brinsley Trench (1911â€“1995): A ufologist and believer in flying saucers and the Hollow Earth theory.
  • Timothy Good (b. 1942): A British researcher and author.
  • Graham Hancock (b. 1950): A British writer and journalist known for his pseudoscientific theories involving ancient civilizations, Earth changes, and related topics.
  • George King (1919â€“1997): Regarded himself as the “Primary Terrestrial Mental Channel” for extraterrestrial intelligences.
  • Elizabeth Klarer (1910â€“1984): A South African contactee and UFO photographer.

This section lists ufologists from the United States.

  • George Adamski (1891â€“1965): A controversial UFO contactee and known hoaxer who wrote about encounters with “space brothers.”
  • Orfeo Angelucci (1912â€“1993): A UFO contactee.

  • Jerome Clark (b. 1946): A UFO historian and author of the UFO Encyclopedia.
  • Philip J. Corso (1915â€“1998): An Army Military Intelligence officer who wrote a disputed book on the Roswell incident.
  • Robert Dean (1929â€“2018): A ufologist who claimed to have read a NATO report on UFOs.
  • Tom DeLonge (b. 1975): Singer and guitarist of blink-182 and founder of To the Stars Academy of Arts and Sciences.
  • Glenn Dennis (1925â€“2015): Founder of the International UFO Museum and Research Center in Roswell, New Mexico, and a self-professed witness to the Roswell incident.
  • Danielle Egnew (b. 1969): An American psychic/medium and paranormal radio, TV, and film host who reports on communication with extraterrestrial species.
  • Raymond E. Fowler (b. 1934): A long-time UFO investigator and author of The Andreasson Affair and The Allagash Abductions.
  • Daniel Fry (1908â€“1992): An American contactee who claimed to have had multiple contacts with an alien and taken a ride in an alien spacecraft.
  • Steven M. Greer (b. 1955): An American physician and proponent of openness regarding advanced technologies believed to be hidden from public awareness.
  • Richard H. Hall (1930â€“2009): Former assistant Director of NICAP and director of the Fund for UFO Research.
  • Charles I. Halt (b. 1939): A retired USAF Colonel and key figure in the Rendlesham UFO incident.
  • Robert L. Hastings (b. 1950): An author and photographer who investigates UFO appearances around nuclear facilities.
  • Allan Hendry (b. 1950): An astronomer and UFO investigator for the Center for UFO Studies.
  • Budd Hopkins (1931â€“2011): An alien abduction researcher.
  • J. Allen Hynek (1910â€“1986): An astronomer

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. These individuals are often referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” While most scientists and mental health professionals attribute these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology, some researchers give credence to the claims. Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, often focusing on reproductive systems, warnings against environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or interspecies breeding. The content of these narratives often varies with the abductee’s cultural background.

Overview ðŸ”—

Mainstream scientists generally reject the literal interpretation of alien abduction claims. However, figures like psychiatrist John E. Mack have argued that many abductees are sane individuals reporting genuine experiences. A subculture has developed around the phenomenon, complete with support groups and a detailed mythos involving various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics) with specific roles and motivations. Some abductees explain the lack of wider awareness as a result of extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History ðŸ”—

Paleo-abductions ðŸ”—

Before the widespread attention to alien abduction in the 1960s, some older stories have been reinterpreted as possible early cases, termed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark. Examples include:

  • A November 27, 1896, report in The Evening Mail of Stockton, California, where Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them.
  • A 1953 Man to Man Magazine article questioning if humans were being captured by flying saucers for zoological specimens or vivisection.
  • Harold T. Wilkins’s 1955 publication Flying Saucers Uncensored, which reported speculation that Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who claimed alien contact, disappeared due to abduction by flying saucers.

Two Landmark Cases ðŸ”—

The Brazilian AntÃ´nio Vilas-Boas case in the mid-1950s was an early claim, but the Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961 gained widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, possibly the first to describe beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin. Skeptic Peter Rogerson notes that these cases established a template for later abductions.

Later Developments ðŸ”—

R. Leo Sprinkle, a University of Wyoming psychologist, became interested in the phenomenon in the 1960s and believed in its actuality, linking abductions to cattle mutilation. Budd Hopkins became a figurehead of the abductee subculture in the 1970s, using hypnosis to extract details. The 1980s brought mainstream attention through works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack, presenting alien abduction as plausible. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard also published a comparative analysis of alleged abductees.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was more common than suspected, estimating tens of thousands of North Americans had been taken. They proposed an alien effort to create human-alien hybrids, with the most advanced stage known as hubrids. While anecdotal reports of phantom pregnancies related to UFO encounters existed earlier, Hopkins and Jacobs popularized the idea of systematic interbreeding efforts.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Michael Shermer noted that camera phones increase the burden of evidence.

John E. Mack ðŸ”—

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, criticized Mack for uncritically elaborating on abduction tales and potentially constructing false memories. Mack’s work in hypnotic regression helped spread the Grey aliens meme. Despite his esteemed reputation, Mack’s belief in abduction claims led to a Harvard review in 1994, where he retained tenure but lost professional credibility among colleagues.

Abductees ðŸ”—

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. Early studies found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys suggested 5â€“6 percent of the general population allege abduction.

Demographics ðŸ”—

While abduction reports are usually made by adults, children sometimes report similar experiences with specific details in common with adult reports. These child reports often feature family members who have reported abduction experiences, and family involvement in the military or residence near a military base is also common.

Mental Health ðŸ”—

Some studies suggest abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show no difference in psychopathology prevalence compared to the general population. Elizabeth Slater’s blind study found abductees prone to “mildly paranoid thinking,” nightmares, and weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally’s study found no psychiatric illness in abductees.

Political Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlighted links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, and government takeover. He observed the rise of “improvisional millenarism.” UFO and abduction stories can be part of stigmatized knowledge narratives, where alleged orthodoxy is claimed to be maintained for nefarious purposes. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

Barkun noted that popular culture, such as The X-Files, included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies and demonized FEMA. Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities and may resort to questionable regression therapy. Some espouse conspiracy theories of technological mind control, including implants, to force them to serve a New World Order or for the purposes of the antichrist.

Abduction Narrative ðŸ”—

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. CUFOS defines an abductee as someone taken against their will by non-human beings to an extraterrestrial place or spaceship, subjected to examination or communication, with memory of the experience either conscious or recovered through hypnosis.

Though cases vary, folklorist Thomas E. Bullard argues there is a fairly consistent sequence of events in a typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.”

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and sometimes simulated behavioral situations, training, testing, or sexual liaisons.
  3. Conference: The abductors communicate with the abductee or direct them to interact with specific individuals, typically telepathically.
  4. Tour: The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Abductees often rapidly forget the majority of their experience.
  6. Return: The abductees are returned to earth, sometimes in a different location or with new injuries.
  7. Theophany: Abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high,” or a “mystical experience.”
  8. Aftermath: The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs says the entire abduction event is precisely orchestrated with predetermined procedures.

Capture ðŸ”—

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the experience, such as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place or expectations of something “familiar yet unknown.” They also report severe anxiety. This period of foreboding can last for days or be absent.

Eventually, the experiencer undergoes an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness, called “the Oz Factor” by British researchers. External sounds cease to have significance, and the experiencer feels introspective and calm. This marks a transition to “limited self-willed mobility.” Lights appear, sometimes accompanied by a strange mist. The source and nature of the lights differ by report.

As the abduction proceeds, claimants say they walk or are levitated into an alien craft, sometimes through solid objects. Alternatively, they may experience rising through a tunnel or along a beam of light into the craft.

Examination ðŸ”—

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. These procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. The entity in charge is often taller and of a different species.

John G. Miller notes different areas of emphasis between human medicine and what is reported by abductors, focusing on the cranium, nervous system, skin, reproductive system, and joints. Systems like the cardiovascular and respiratory systems receive less attention. Abductors do not appear to wear gloves, and terrestrial medicine constants like pills and tongue depressors are missing.

Subsequent Procedures ðŸ”—

After the medical exam, abductees often report other procedures, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

“Imaging” involves viewing screens displaying images intended to provoke emotional responses. “Envisioning” is similar, but the images are projected into the experiencer’s mind. “Staging” involves the abductee playing an active role in a vivid, hallucination-like scenario. “Testing” involves the experiencer operating a complicated electronic device, often finding they know how to operate it despite initial confusion.

Child Presentation ðŸ”—

Abductees sometimes report being subjected

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. These individuals are often referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” While most scientists and mental health professionals attribute these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology, some researchers give credence to the claims. Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, often focusing on reproductive systems, warnings about environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or interspecies breeding. The content of these narratives often varies with the abductee’s cultural background.

Overview ðŸ”—

Mainstream scientists generally reject the literal interpretation of alien abduction claims. However, some, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals, with psychopathology only present in some cases. Detailed abduction reports have led to the development of a subculture with support groups and a complex mythos explaining the roles, origins, and motivations of various alien types, such as Greys, Reptilians, and Nordics. Some abductees engage in independent research and attribute the lack of wider awareness to extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History ðŸ”—

Paleo-abductions ðŸ”—

Before the widespread attention to alien abduction in the 1960s, some older stories have been reinterpreted as possible early cases, termed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark. One example is Colonel H. G. Shaw’s 1896 claim of being harassed by tall, slender humanoids. An article from 1953 asked if flying saucers were kidnapping humans for zoological specimens or vivisection. The 1955 publication of Harold T. Wilkins’s Flying Saucers Uncensored reported speculation that Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who claimed alien contact, disappeared due to abduction.

Two landmark cases ðŸ”—

The AntÃ´nio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil during the mid-1950s was an early claim but received limited attention initially. The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961 gained widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, possibly the first to describe beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin.

Later developments ðŸ”—

R. Leo Sprinkle, a psychologist at the University of Wyoming, became interested in the phenomenon in the 1960s and linked abductions to cattle mutilation. Budd Hopkins became a key figure in the abductee subculture in the 1970s, using hypnosis to uncover details of remembered events. The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience. Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was more common than previously thought, estimating tens of thousands of North Americans had been abducted. They also proposed an alien effort to create human-alien hybrids. While anecdotal reports of phantom pregnancies related to UFO encounters existed earlier, Hopkins and Jacobs popularized the idea of widespread interbreeding efforts.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, alien abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Michael Shermer suggests that the ubiquity of camera phones has increased the burden of evidence, contributing to the decline.

John E. Mack ðŸ”—

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, suggested that Mack’s work in hypnotic regression helped spread the Grey aliens meme. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject. His professional reputation suffered due to his belief and promotion of abduction claims, leading to a Harvard review in 1994.

Abductees ðŸ”—

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. Early studies found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys suggested 5â€“6 percent of the general population claim to have been abducted.

Demographics ðŸ”—

While abduction reports are usually made by adults, children sometimes report similar experiences. These reports often share specific details with adult reports, including circumstances, narrative, entities, and aftermaths. Young abductees often have family members who have reported abduction experiences, and family involvement in the military or residence near a military base is also common.

Mental health ðŸ”—

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that abductees are not different from the general population in terms of psychopathology prevalence. Elizabeth Slater’s blind study found abductees prone to “mildly paranoid thinking,” nightmares, and weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally’s study concluded that none of the abductees suffered from psychiatric illness.

Political conspiracy theories ðŸ”—

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, and government takeover. He observed the rise of “improvisional millenarism.” UFO and abduction stories can be part of stigmatized knowledge narratives. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

According to Barkun, TV shows like The X-Files included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies, with militias and black helicopters, and demonized FEMA. Political scientist Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities and may resort to questionable regression therapy. Some espouse conspiracy theories of technological mind control, including implants, to force them to serve a New World Order or for the purposes of the antichrist.

Abduction narrative ðŸ”—

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. CUFOS defines an abductee as someone taken against their will by non-human beings to an extraterrestrial place or spaceship, subjected to examination or communication, with memories that may be conscious or recovered through hypnosis.

Although cases vary, some UFO researchers argue that there is a fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.”

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures, and on occasion simulated behavioral situations, training & testing, or sexual liaisons.
  3. Conference: The abductors communicate with the abductee or direct them to interact with specific individuals for some purpose.
  4. Tour: The abductees are given a tour of their captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Abductees often rapidly forget the majority of their experience.
  6. Return: The abductees are returned to earth, occasionally in a different location or with new injuries.
  7. Theophany: Abductees may have a profound sense of love, a “high” similar to those induced by certain drugs, or a “mystical experience”.
  8. Aftermath: The abductee must cope with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs says that the entire abduction event is precisely orchestrated, with predetermined procedures.

Capture ðŸ”—

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience, such as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place or expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will occur. They also report feeling severe anxiety. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. External sounds cease to have any significance, and they report feeling introspective and unusually calm. As consciousness shifts, lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, often through solid objects.

Examination ðŸ”—

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. Such procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. The entity in charge of the operation is often taller than the others and may appear to be of a different species.

Miller notes different areas of emphasis between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors. The abductors’ areas of interest appear to be the cranium, nervous system, skin, reproductive system, and joints. Systems given less attention include the cardiovascular system, the respiratory system below the pharynx, and the lymphatic system. The abductors also appear to ignore the upper region of the abdomen in favor of the lower one. The abductors do not appear to wear gloves during the “examination.” Other constants of terrestrial medicine like pills and tablets are missing from abduction narratives, although sometimes abductees are asked to drink liquids.

Subsequent procedures ðŸ”—

After the medical exam, the alleged abductees often report other procedures being performed with the entities. Common among these post-examination procedures are imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

“Imaging” procedures consist of an abductee being made to view screens displaying images and scenes that appear to be specially chosen with the intent to provoke certain emotional responses in the abductee. “Envisioning” is a similar procedure, with the primary difference being that the images being viewed, rather than being on a screen, actually seem to be

item.title: Ufology
item.description:
Ufology ðŸ”—

Ufology is the investigation of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) by individuals who believe they may have extraordinary origins, often extraterrestrial. While governments, private groups, and fringe science may investigate UFOs, ufology is generally considered pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators.

Etymology ðŸ”—

The term “ufology” is a neologism derived from “UFO” and the suffix “-logy.” Edward J. Ruppelt is credited with coining the term UFO. Early uses of “ufology” appeared in a 1957 Fantastic Universe article and a 1958 presentation for The Planetary Center.

Historical background ðŸ”—

Ufology’s roots can be traced to several historical phenomena: the “mystery airships” of the late 1890s, “foo fighters” reported during World War II, “ghost fliers” of the 1930s, “ghost rockets” in Scandinavia in 1946, and the Kenneth Arnold “flying saucer” sighting in 1947. The Arnold sighting significantly popularized the concept of flying saucers.

Increased UFO publicity after World War II coincided with the Cold War and concerns about Soviet aircraft. Official government activities related to ufology in the United States ended in the late 1960s after the Condon Committee report and the termination of Project Blue Book. Similar government-sponsored activities in other countries, such as the United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, Italy, and Sweden, also ended. France is an exception, maintaining the GEIPAN program.

In September 2023, NASA appointed Mark McInerney as the Director of U.A.P. to study such occurrences scientifically and transparently.

As a field ðŸ”—

Status as a pseudoscience ðŸ”—

Ufology is not recognized as a scientific field by academia and is generally considered a pseudoscience by skeptics and science educators. Pseudoscience lacks adherence to the scientific method, supporting evidence, plausibility, or falsifiability.

Social factors contribute to ufology’s status as a pseudoscience. Some argue that mistrust between ufology, the sciences, and government bodies contributes to this status. Poor science communication regarding the extraterrestrial intelligence (ETI) hypothesis for UFOs hinders public understanding and discourages academic inquiry.

Current interest ðŸ”—

In 2021, Avi Loeb launched The Galileo Project to collect scientific evidence of extraterrestrials or their technology near Earth.

The University of WÃ¼rzburg in Germany is developing sensors to detect and analyze aerial objects, potentially applicable to UAP.

A 2021 Gallup poll indicated an increase in the belief among Americans that some UFOs are extraterrestrial spacecraft.

In 2022, NASA announced a study to establish a roadmap for investigating UAP.

In 2023, the RAND Corporation published a study reviewing public reports of UAP sightings in the United States from 1998 to 2022.

Methodological issues ðŸ”—

Scientific UFO research faces challenges due to the unpredictable nature of the phenomena, lack of reproducibility, and absence of tangible physicality. Most UFO sightings have mundane explanations, limiting the interpretive power of extraordinary events. Carl Sagan noted that reliable cases are uninteresting, and interesting cases are unreliable.

J. Allen Hynek and Jacques VallÃ©e developed descriptive systems for characterizing UFO sightings and organizing ufology investigations.

Phenomena linked to ufology ðŸ”—

Certain phenomena are of interest to some ufologists, including crop circles, cattle mutilations, anomalous materials, alien abductions, and implants.

Some ufologists promote UFO conspiracy theories, including the Roswell Incident, Majestic 12 documents, and UFO disclosure advocates.

Robert Sheaffer has accused ufology of a “credulity explosion,” where increasingly outlandish stories gain traction. James E. McDonald identified “cultism” and “extreme subgroups” as negatively impacting ufology.

In Posadism ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, ufology was synthesized with Posadism, a Trotskyist movement in South America. Juan Posadas, the main theorist, believed humanity should appeal to extraterrestrials to collaborate in suppressing poverty and creating a socialist system on Earth. This belief contributed to the decline of Posadism.

Governmental and private ufology studies ðŸ”—

Starting in the 1940s, governmental agencies and private groups sponsored investigations, studies, and conferences related to ufology. These studies include Project Sign, Project Magnet, Project Blue Book, the Robertson Panel, and the Condon Committee in the United States; the Flying Saucer Working Party and Project Condign in Britain; GEIPAN in France; and Project Hessdalen in Norway. Private studies include those by the RAND Corporation, Harvey Rutledge of the University of Missouri, and the National Press Club’s Disclosure Project. The United Nations sponsored meetings and hearings concerning UFO sightings from 1977 to 1979. In August 2020, the United States Department of Defense established the Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force to detect, analyze, and catalog unidentified aerial phenomena.

UFO organizations and events ðŸ”—

Numerous private organizations worldwide are dedicated to the study, discussion, and publicity of ufology. Skeptic organizations emphasize the pseudoscientific nature of ufology.

During World UFO Day (July 2), ufologists raise public awareness of ufology, including group gatherings to search for and observe UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ufological

item.title: List of humanoid aliens
item.description:
List of Humanoid Aliens ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry is a compilation of fictional extraterrestrial humanoid characters from various media. It emphasizes that these aliens possess human-like traits such as upright posture, bipedalism, opposable thumbs, and facial features. The list is organized by medium: Animation, Comics, Film, Literature, Television, and Video Games. Each entry includes the character’s name, origin (the work in which they appear), and brief notes about their role or characteristics. The article is flagged as needing additional citations for verification and may not be complete.

Animation ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in animated works. Key characters include:

  • The Great Gazoo (The Flintstones): A tiny alien exiled to Earth who can only be seen by Fred, Barney, children, and animals.
  • Cure Princess/Hime Shirayuki (HappinessCharge PreCure!): A princess from the Blue Sky Kingdom.
  • Mikitaka Hazekura (JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure): An alien who appears as a teenage boy with pointed ears.
  • Interplanet Janet (Schoolhouse Rock): A cyborg girl from another galaxy.
  • Jet Propulsion (Ready Jet Go!): An alien from Bortron 7 studying Earth.
  • Cure Milky/Lala Hagoromo (Star Twinkle PreCure): An alien from the planet Samaan.
  • Little Twelvetoes (Schoolhouse Rock): A jovial alien with green skin and six fingers and toes.
  • Marvin the Martian (Looney Tunes): A Martian often accompanied by his dog K-9.
  • Ozmodiar (The Simpsons): A parody of The Great Gazoo, only visible to Homer Simpson.
  • Roger (American Dad!): An alien living in Stan’s attic.
  • Sailor Starlights (Sailor Moon): Sailor Guardians from Planet Kinmoku.
  • Shadow Galactica (Sailor Moon): Antagonists from various planets in the Milky Way.
  • Son Goku (Dragon Ball): A Saiyan from Planet Vegeta.
  • Cure Cosmo/Yuni (Star Twinkle PreCure): A shapeshifting catgirl from Planet Rainbow.
  • Zim (Invader Zim): An Irken invader sent to conquer Earth.
  • Upgrade (Ben 10): A Galvanic Mechamorph from Galvan B.
  • Atomix (Ben 10): An alien from an unknown planet who can create nuclear energy.

Comics ðŸ”—

This section details humanoid aliens from comic books. Notable entries include:

  • Annihilus (Fantastic Four): A villain from the Marvel Universe. Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.
  • Cosmo (Cosmo the Merry Martian): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Bob White.
  • Darna (Darna): An extraterrestrial warrior who manifests in a human girl. Created by Mars Ravelo and Nestor Redondo.
  • KhÃ¢ny (Yoko Tsuno): An alien from the planet Vinea. Created by Roger Leloup.
  • Plunk (Plunk): An alien from the planet Smurk. Created by Luc Cromheecke and Laurent Letzer.
  • The Scrameustache (Scrameustache): An alien with a cat-like face. Created by Roland Goossens (Gos).
  • Mr. Skygack (Mr. Skygack, from Mars): A Martian studying human behavior. Created by A.D. Condo.
  • Superman/Clark Kent (Action Comics #1): An alien from Krypton with superhuman powers. Created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster.
  • Xal-Kor (Xal-Kor the Human Cat): An alien from Felis who can transform between cat, hybrid, and human forms. Created by Grass Green.
  • Zook (Zook): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in movies. Key examples include:

  • E.T. (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial): An alien who befriends a human boy.
  • Various (Marvel Cinematic Universe): Includes Asgardians, members of the Guardians of the Galaxy, and Eternals.
  • Klaatu (The Day the Earth Stood Still): An alien who delivers a peaceful message to Earth.
  • Various (Star Wars): Includes Chewbacca, Yoda, Darth Maul, and Ahsoka Tano.
  • Zaphod Beeblebrox (The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy): An alien from near Betelgeuse.
  • Mork (Mork and Mindy): An alien from Ork who studies humanity on Earth.
  • The Alien Girl (Super Deluxe): An alien living on Earth, mingling with humans.

Literature ðŸ”—

This section compiles humanoid aliens from literary works. Notable characters include:

  • The Little Prince (The Little Prince): A prince from an asteroid who visits Earth.
  • Curtis (One Door Away from Heaven): A shape-shifting alien on the run.
  • Ras Thavas (The Master Mind of Mars): A Martian mad scientist.
  • The Thing (Who Goes There?): A shapeshifting alien that takes a human form.

Television ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in television shows. Key characters include:

  • Adric (Doctor Who): A young native of Alzarius in E-Space.
  • ALF/Gordon Shumway (ALF): An alien from Melmac who crash lands on Earth.
  • Beldar, Prymaat, and Connie (Coneheads): An alien family from Remulak with conical heads.
  • Big Giant Head (3rd Rock from the Sun): The alien leader of the Solomons.
  • The Doctor (Doctor Who): An adventurer and scientist.
  • FofÃ£o (BalÃ£o MÃ¡gico and TV FofÃ£o): An extraterrestrial child character.
  • Gonzo (The Muppet Show): A puppet revealed to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Mork (Mork & Mindy): An alien from Ork who befriends a human woman.
  • Martin O’Hara (My Favorite Martian): A Martian anthropologist stranded on Earth.
  • Dick Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Harry Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Sally Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Tommy Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Spock (Star Trek): A Vulcan science officer on the Enterprise.
  • Ultraman (Ultraman): A race of aliens who protect the universe.
  • Ultronians (My Hero): A species from the planet Ultron with superpowers.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in video games. Key examples include:

  • Abe (Oddworld): The central character of the Oddworld series.
  • Artanis (StarCraft): A Protoss commander and protagonist.
  • Forerunner (Halo): Ancient Humanoid Aliens that created the Halo rings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_humanoid_aliens

item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in DC Comics ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive list of extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics, including comic books and other media. It provides brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Overview ðŸ”—

The DC Comics universe contains a vast number of alien races, most of which are humanoid.

United Planets ðŸ”—

The United Planets is a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. Members include planets of the Solar System, Htrae, artificial planet-sized satellites, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. In the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros.

0-9 ðŸ”—

5th Dimensional Imps ðŸ”—

Zrfff is the homeworld of 5th Dimensional Imps, including Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Brpxz, Mister Genie (Genro), Quisp, Bat-Mite, Kcid Nosyarg (Larry), Zook, Gazook, and Mopee. In other media, 5th Dimensional Imps appear in Supergirl, consisting of Mxyzptlk and Gsptlsnz / Nyxlygsptlnz. The Music Meister is revealed to be an imp in a Supergirl crossover with The Flash.

A ðŸ”—

Adaptoids ðŸ”—

The Adaptoids are blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus that attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans ðŸ”—

The Aellans are yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello (Stormswift), Demonia, Harpis, and Doc of Aello were all members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders ðŸ”—

The Alien Invaders are the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci ðŸ”—

The Almeraci are a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the House of the Blood Royale, a matriarchy of superpowered monarchs. They choose mates through ceremonial gladiatorial competitions. Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and her onetime betrothed Ultraa represent this species.

Aloi ðŸ”—

The Aloi are blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device known as the “Grayl”. Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans ðŸ”—

The Alstairans of Alstair are plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, one of four technologically advanced spacefaring races native to the Antares system. Their ruler is the alien plant elemental Hyathis.

Anasazi ðŸ”—

The Anasazi are metahumans resettled to planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Andromedans ðŸ”—

The Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy are a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites, with red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak was exiled to Earth and later cured by Superman and Vartox.

Angtuans ðŸ”—

The Angtuans are inhabitants of the planet Angtu, a world with a thick, noxious atmosphere. Angtu was destroyed in the 30th century by the mutated native Mano.

Anunnake ðŸ”—

The Anunnake are reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs; they are also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann ðŸ”—

The Anndrann are green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, later banished to Bellatrix, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a deleterious effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians ðŸ”—

The Appellaxians of Appellax are technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies for their minds. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. The Justice League first came together because of them. In Young Justice, Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem using a Mother Box, before it is destroyed by Black Beetle.

Aipitons ðŸ”—

The Aipitons are the presumed name of a species of small flying insects of the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids ðŸ”—

The Aquoids are natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes ðŸ”—

The Aranes of Arane II are light blue-skinned, white-haired humanoids with tiny blue protruding horns on their foreheads. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans ðŸ”—

The Ardenans are the presumed name of a sentient race of humanoids with orange scaly skin from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians ðŸ”—

The Astonians are a minor alien race under a once dying star saved by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker upon facing extinction. Saint Walker is of this race.

Azarathians ðŸ”—

The Azarathians are people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B ðŸ”—

Barrions ðŸ”—

The Barrions of Barrio III are silicon-based lifeforms, represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers ðŸ”—

The Bellatrix Bombers are alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians ðŸ”—

The Bgztlians are humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Blight ðŸ”—

The Blight are a cybernetic race whose bodies are composed of rotting flesh and villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos.

Bloodline Parasites ðŸ”—

The eight Bloodline Parasites were extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of accidentally activating the human metagene during the act of feeding on human spinal fluid.

Braalians ðŸ”—

The Braalians are humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes are their representatives.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X ðŸ”—

The Brain-Parasites of Planet X hail from Planet X and use powerful Knowledge-Extractors to steal knowledge from other races.

Branx ðŸ”—

The Branx of Emana Branx are a gray-skinned race of dull-witted, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians.

Brylyx ðŸ”—

The Brylyx are white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians ðŸ”—

The Bolovax Vikians are highly communal and technologically advanced. Bolovax Vikians of Bolovax Vik are a dead race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member of this species. A holographic Bolovax Vikian appears in the My Adventures with Superman episode “The Machine Who Would Be Empire”.

Bugs of New Genesis ðŸ”—

The Bugs of New Genesis are an insectoid race who were spread on New Genesis during their war with Apokolips. Forager and Mantis are the most prominent members of the race.

C ðŸ”—

Cairnians ðŸ”—

The Cairnians are members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians ðŸ”—

The Calatonians are an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by the Doomsday creature.

Canopians ðŸ”—

The Canopians are a member of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites ðŸ”—

The Carggites are humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes is their representative.

Catherix ðŸ”—

The Cathexis are a race of alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality endangering technology.

Changralynians ðŸ”—

The Changralynians of Changralyn are a race of silicon-based pacifists, they are represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Children of Tanjent ðŸ”—

The Children of Tanjent are a psionic race.

Circadians ðŸ”—

The peaceful insectoid Circadians of Circadia established a joint human/Circadian settlement in the 30th Century known as Pax Colony. Circadia Senius is a Chronarch Research Fellow at the Metropolis Time Institute and a friend of Brainiac 5.

Citadelians ðŸ”—

The Citadelians of the Citadel are a race of sadistic imperialistic clones, whose intellect and genetic viability degrades with each newly cloned generation.

Clementians ðŸ”—

The Clementians of Clementia are also known as “Black Mercies”. The Green Lantern Mother Mercy is the caretaker and ruler of the Clementian race.

Coluans ðŸ”—

The Coluans (sometimes known as Yod-Colu) of Colu are a hyper-intelligent species, one of the most technologically advanced in the known universe. They are most notably represented by the various men and women who hold the title of Brainiac along with Pulsar Stargrave. The planet Colu was destroyed by the Omega Titans in Justice League: No Justice. The Coluans appear in *

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanagarian

item.title: Alien language
item.description:
Alien Language ðŸ”—

This article discusses the hypothetical concept of alien languages, exploring the challenges and possibilities of understanding and communicating with extraterrestrial beings. It delves into the field of study dedicated to these hypothetical languages, the opinions of linguists on the matter, and examples of how the topic has been approached in science fiction.

Hypothetical Non-Earth Language ðŸ”—

This section introduces the concept of alien languages as a hypothetical subject due to the lack of confirmed contact with extraterrestrial life. It mentions the various names for the study of these languages, including exolinguistics, xenolinguistics, and astrolinguistics. The section also references the book Xenolinguistics: Towards a Science of Extraterrestrial Language, edited by Douglas Vakoch and Jeffrey Punske, which features contributions from prominent linguists like Noam Chomsky. It also mentions that the topic of alien languages has been included in linguistics and language studies courses, such as at Bowling Green State University.

ðŸ”—

This section presents Noam Chomsky’s view that humans might not be able to naturally learn an alien language due to the constraints of a genetically predetermined universal grammar. He suggests that understanding an alien language would require a scientific approach, similar to research in physics.

ðŸ”—

This section highlights Keren Rice’s more optimistic perspective, suggesting that basic communication between humans and aliens should be possible if fundamental aspects of language, such as time, space, and participants, are not radically different.

ðŸ”—

This section discusses Jessica Coon’s involvement as a linguistic consultant for the film Arrival. While acknowledging the artistic license taken with the alien language in the film, she notes that the film accurately portrays the approach human linguists would take in attempting to decipher an alien language.

ðŸ”—

This section mentions Laurance Doyle’s suggestion of using Zipf’s law to detect alien language within the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI).

ðŸ”—

This section presents Solomon W. Golomb’s argument that any civilization capable of interstellar communication must possess an innate understanding that information retains its meaning regardless of the speaker. He posits that this shared understanding would facilitate the learning of extraterrestrial languages.

ðŸ”—

This section includes a quote from Ian Roberts, a professor of linguistics at the University of Cambridge, who emphasizes the unique open-endedness of human language. Roberts is also mentioned as being on the Advisory Council of Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence (METI), an organization that sends messages into space in hopes of receiving a reply.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including:

  • Alien language in science fiction
  • Animal language
  • Astrolinguistics
  • Communication with extraterrestrial intelligence
  • Interspecies communication

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing credibility and allowing readers to further explore the topics discussed.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_language

item.title: Ashtar (extraterrestrial being)
item.description:
Ashtar (Extraterrestrial Being) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on Ashtar, an alleged extraterrestrial being or group of beings, primarily within the context of ufology and UFO religions. It notes the “unbalanced” tag, indicating potential bias in viewpoints.

Folklore ðŸ”—

This section identifies the subject as belonging to the realm of ufology.

First Attested ðŸ”—

The first recorded claim of contact with Ashtar dates back to 1952.

Other Name(s) ðŸ”—

Ashtar is also known by variations of the name, including Ashtar Sheran, Captain Ashtar, Commander Ashtar, and Lord Ashtar.

Country ðŸ”—

The initial claims and development of the Ashtar figure originated in the United States.

Ashtar ðŸ”—

This section introduces Ashtar as an alleged extraterrestrial being or group of beings that some people claim to have channeled. It mentions George Van Tassel as the first person to claim contact with Ashtar in 1952. It also notes that after Van Tassel’s initial claims, many other mediums began to claim contact, often presenting conflicting messages. The failure of predictions made through these channels, such as flourishing civilizations on other planets and imminent landings of spaceships, is also mentioned. Ashtar’s common depiction as a humanoid with blond hair and European features is noted, linking him to the Nordic alien archetype. The Ashtar movement is studied as a prominent form of UFO religion, with the Czech Universe People being an example of a religion that venerates Ashtar alongside figures like Jesus and Krishna.

History ðŸ”—

This section introduces the historical context of the Ashtar figure within the broader history of UFO religions and esoteric teachings.

Background ðŸ”—

This section discusses the background of Ashtar within the context of UFO religions and the reappearance of “Ascended Masters” in spacesuits. It traces the concept back to Theosophy and Helena Blavatsky’s The Secret Doctrine, where “ashtar-vidya” refers to advanced warfare technology in the Mahabharata. George Van Tassel’s role in propagating the contactee movement is highlighted, particularly his establishment of a UFO Center at Giant Rock, California, which became a prominent meeting place. Van Tassel’s “Ministry of Universal Wisdom,” founded in 1953, is mentioned as a key organization for investigating UFO phenomena and interviewing contactees.

Purported contact with Van Tassel ðŸ”—

This section details George Van Tassel’s claims of telepathic communication with Ashtar starting in 1952. Van Tassel interpreted the Bible in terms of extraterrestrial intervention and claimed Jesus was a being from space. He taught that humans could tap into the “Universal Mind of God” and receive messages from Ashtar and deceased individuals like Nikola Tesla. From Tesla, he claimed to receive instructions to build the “Integratron” machine. Van Tassel’s early messages from Ashtar focused on apocalyptic concerns regarding the hydrogen bomb, with Ashtar entering the Solar System as Commander in Chief of the Ashtar Galactic Command to warn humanity. The messages claimed the space command was helping humanity and that Ashtar provided messages for the U.S. government. Van Tassel claimed his method of communication was a new form of telepathy utilizing advanced alien technology, rather than traditional spiritual mediumship.

Giant Rock Space Conventions ðŸ”—

This section describes the weekly channeling sessions held by Van Tassel at Giant Rock, which helped coalesce the contactee subculture. These gatherings led to the annual Giant Rock Spacecraft Convention, which began in 1953 and continued for at least 24 years. In 1959, up to 11,000 people attended these conventions and heard channeled messages claiming to come from space. Most of the well-known UFO contactees attended as speakers and channelers. J. Gordon Melton notes that almost all of the 1950s contactees became involved in the ecumenical structures founded by Van Tassel or Gabriel Green. Most of the early messages Van Tassel claimed to have received from Ashtar were first presented to the public at these events.

Ashtar Command ðŸ”—

This section discusses the appropriation of the “Ashtar Command” concept by other contactees and channelers, based on Van Tassel’s Ashtar figure. Robert Short (AKA Bill Rose), editor of Interplanetary News Digest, popularized the messages but broke away from Van Tassel to form his own group called “Ashtar Command.” By the mid-1950s, the concept of Ashtar and a galactic law enforcement agency preparing to rescue humanity had become well-established, including channelers like Elouise Moeller and Adelaide J. Brown. The public failure of predictions had a negative impact on the movement due to the lack of a central authority. Dozens of Ashtar channelers presented conflicting messages.

Development into spiritual religion (1990s onward) ðŸ”—

This section explains the evolution of the Ashtar message from an early contact account to a more spiritual message, with Ashtar taking on the role of an Ascended Master. The Ashtar Command evolved into a diffuse New Age Spiritualist milieu, with teachings varying immensely. Tuella founded Guardian Action International. Andreas Grunschloss describes much of the Ashtar channeling as akin to cargo cults, blending spiritual ascension with new alien technologies. Millenarian concepts involved a transformation of human beings via these technologies, who would then return to Earth to enjoy a golden millennium. Later, with the failure of these prophecies, teachings were modified to include a less material and more spiritual emphasis.

1970s broadcasts ðŸ”—

This section mentions a 1971 British radio talk show that received a strange call-in claiming to originate from outer space. It also discusses the 1977 Southern Television broadcast interruption, when a voice calling itself “Vrillon” of the Ashtar Galactic Command temporarily took over a television transmitter in southern England.

1986 prediction of 1994 apocalypse ðŸ”—

This section details Yvonne Cole’s predictions, claiming to channel Ashtar messages from 1986, of the destruction of all Earth civilizations and the arrival of alien cultures in 1994. Cole claimed governments were working with extraterrestrials to prepare for contact, which would be broadcast through the global media and include a message from the Ashtar Command. Ashtar followers would be needed as advisors, ambassadors, and peacekeepers. These prophecies furthered the continued fracturing and disappointment within the movement when they failed to occur. Despite these failures, during the 1980s, a number of individuals began to claim contact with the Ashtar Command through channeling, and various small groups were formed to receive and disseminate the messages.

The 1994 Pioneer Voyage meditations ðŸ”—

This section describes a 1994 event where a small group of Ashtar Command members claimed to have had a “lift-off experience,” being placed aboard “ships of Light” circling the planet. “The Galactic Fifth Fleet” used “physical vibrational transfer” to raise human consciousness to the “Light ships.” A second event was predicted for December 1994, involving over 250 people, which was declared to have “opened a portal to the AC (Ashtar Command) ships for ever.” Participants’ vibrations were raised through an eight-step contemplative procedure, and the Pioneer Voyage would occur during meditation. This evoked “memory recall” from a core group of Ashtar Command members meeting in Australia, who began providing accounts of their “time aboard the ships.” The time on the ships was claimed to be extensive, even though the member’s meditation period was short. The events are claimed to be occurring on a spiritual or etheric dimension, not a physical one. The purpose of the lift-off is for the ascension of the human race, aided by large electronic grids deployed around the planet by the guardian ships.

Developments after the mid-1990s ðŸ”—

This section discusses how, by the mid-1990s, channeling groups began using the Internet to promulgate their beliefs and unify the movement by establishing a single “authoritative” source for all Ashtar messages. This led to more prominence in the religious scene and significant membership. This cohesive response addressed the problem of conflicting, negative, and failed prophecies, enabling the Ashtar Command to produce a single Ashtar worldview. Individual channelers espousing messages which differed and continued to focus on themes such as the destruction of Earth, conspiracies, extraterrestrial mass evacuations, and general fear-mongering were declared invalid. These channelers had been deceived by negative space beings who had rebelled from the Ashtar Command. The new, more unified movement declared that in the future, no new channels would be accepted unless they operated on the “level of the soul.” Channeled messages from Ashtar would be accepted as valid by the new orthodoxy if they complied with criteria consisting of a set of twelve guidelines which outlined what the movement stood for and how Ashtar would interact with society. The millions of spaceships believed to be constantly in the vicinity of Earth would never interfere on the planet’s surface unless there was a serious problem such as a third world war or an “astrophysical catastrophe.” The emergent group was “noticeably more spiritually focused and less concerned with extraterrestrial spaceships and visitors.” Very little distinguished the new Ashtar Command from other theosophically influenced groups, except that in 1994 a distinctive component, the Pioneer Voyage, was incorporated into the Ashtar worldview.

Credibility ðŸ”—

This section addresses the credibility of Ashtar claims, pointing out the failure of the July 1952 prediction channeled through Van Tassel

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashtar_(extraterrestrial_being)

item.title: Lists of fictional extraterrestrials
item.description:
Lists of Fictional Extraterrestrial Species ðŸ”—

This page serves as a central index for various lists cataloging fictional extraterrestrial species found across different media. It also provides links to related topics like fictional species in general.

Alphabetical ðŸ”—

This section provides a comprehensive alphabetical listing of links to individual pages, each dedicated to fictional alien species whose names begin with a specific letter of the alphabet. This allows users to quickly navigate to species based on their name. For example, there are links for A, B, C, and so on, up to Z.

By Medium & Franchise ðŸ”—

This section organizes lists of fictional extraterrestrial species based on the specific medium or franchise in which they appear.

Literature ðŸ”—

  • List of Noon Universe alien races: Links to the section on alien races within the Noon Universe, a science fiction setting created by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.

item.title: History of the extraterrestrial life debate
item.description:
Historical Views about Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article explores the historical debate surrounding the existence of extraterrestrial life, tracing its evolution from ancient philosophical speculations to modern scientific inquiry. It highlights key figures, pivotal moments, and shifting perspectives that have shaped our understanding of this enduring question.

Ancient Greece ðŸ”—

This section delves into the earliest recorded discussions about extraterrestrial life, focusing on Ancient Greece. It contrasts the views of atomists, who believed in the possibility of multiple worlds with life, and Aristotelians, who argued for the uniqueness of Earth.

  • Key Points: The section highlights the shift from mythological explanations of celestial objects to philosophical inquiries about the nature of the universe.
  • Important People: Thales of Miletus, Anaximander, Pythagoras, Aristarchus of Samos, Plato, Aristotle, Leucippus, Democritus, Epicurus, Lucretius, Alexander the Great.
  • Locations: Ancient Greece, Alexandria, Baghdad, Roman Empire, Byzantine Empire.
  • Major Events: The development of geometry, the proposal of heliocentric and geocentric models, the spread of Greek ideas through the Macedonian Empire and the Islamic Golden Age, and the eventual return of this knowledge to Europe.

Christianity ðŸ”—

This section examines the influence of Christianity on the debate about extraterrestrial life during the Middle Ages. It discusses how the concept of multiple worlds was largely viewed as heretical, with a few exceptions.

  • Key Points: The section focuses on the conflict between religious doctrine and the idea of extraterrestrial life, particularly concerning the uniqueness of creation and the role of Christ’s redemption.
  • Important People: Origen, Augustine of Hippo, Thomas Aquinas, William Vorilong, John.
  • Major Events: The rise of Christianity, the Condemnation of 1277, and the discussions surrounding the implications of extraterrestrial life for Christian theology.

Copernican Revolution ðŸ”—

This section explores how the Copernican Revolution, which shifted the Earth from the center of the universe, significantly impacted the plausibility of extraterrestrial life.

  • Key Points: The section highlights the transition from a geocentric to a heliocentric worldview and the scientific advancements that supported this shift.
  • Important People: Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, Galileo Galilei, Isaac Newton, Giordano Bruno.
  • Major Events: The publication of De revolutionibus orbium coelestium, Kepler’s discovery of elliptical orbits, Galileo’s telescopic observations, and Newton’s formulation of the laws of motion and universal gravitation.

Modern Times ðŸ”—

This section discusses the modern scientific approach to the question of extraterrestrial life, encompassing fields like biology, chemistry, biochemistry, physics, and planetary science, all under the umbrella of astrobiology.

  • Key Points: The section emphasizes the vastness and age of the universe, the abundance of elements necessary for life, and the universality of physical laws, which together suggest that life on other worlds is plausible.
  • Major Events: The development of astrobiology as a multidisciplinary field, and the ongoing search for extraterrestrial life through scientific exploration and research.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_extraterrestrial_life_debate

item.title: James Harder
item.description:
James A. Harder ðŸ”—

James Albert Harder was a professor of civil and hydraulic engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, and later a professor emeritus. He also had a notable interest in ufology.

Engineering ðŸ”—

Harder taught civil engineering at various levels, emphasizing practical aspects like lab experiments and model testing. While he didn’t publish extensively, his work was recognized for its quality. He made significant contributions to flow simulations before computers were widely used. A paper he co-authored, Sea Water Intrusion in California, received an award in 1957. His work was applied in Suisun Bay and the Mekong Delta, and he also studied fish protection facilities. Later in his career, he studied fluid mechanics in a medical context, working on artificial hearts, endoscopes, and colostomy equipment.

Ufology ðŸ”—

Harder believed that unidentified flying objects were extraterrestrial beings. He testified before the House of Representatives Committee on Science and Astronautics and was involved with the Aerial Phenomena Research Organization (APRO).

Education ðŸ”—

Harder’s education included:

  • B.S. from the California Institute of Technology in 1948.
  • M.S. in Civil Engineering from UC Berkeley in 1952.
  • Ph.D. in Fluid Mechanics from UC Berkeley in 1957.

Career ðŸ”—

Harder’s career included:

  • U.S. Navy as an electronics technician (1944-45).
  • Design Engineer for the soil conservation service, U.S. Department of Agriculture (1948â€“50).
  • Resident engineer at UC Berkeley (1952â€“57).
  • Assistant professor of hydraulic engineering at UC Berkeley (1957â€“62).
  • Associate professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1962â€“70).
  • Professor of civil engineering at UC Berkeley (1970â€“91).
  • Professor emeritus at UC Berkeley (1991).

Organizations ðŸ”—

Harder was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). He was also a founding member of the Society for Scientific Exploration.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Harder_(ufologist)

item.title: Alien visitation
item.description:
Alien Visitation ðŸ”—

This entry directs readers to the Wiktionary definition of “visitation.”

Alien visitation refers to the concept that intelligent extraterrestrial beings have visited Earth. Several claimed forms of these visitations are listed:

  • Alien abduction: The act of being kidnapped by aliens.
  • Ancient astronaut: The theory that aliens influenced major historical events.
  • Close encounter: The observation of alien vessels.
  • Contactee: A person who claims to have been contacted by aliens.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to a disambiguation page for the term “Visitation,” indicating that the term has multiple meanings beyond the context of alien encounters. It also includes a standard disambiguation notice, explaining that the page lists articles associated with the title “Alien visitation” and advising users to correct internal links that may have led them there unintentionally.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_visitation

item.title: Project Magnet (UFO)
item.description:
Project Magnet ðŸ”—

Project Magnet was a Canadian government-sponsored study of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) established in December 1950 and led by Wilbert Brockhouse Smith. The project was formally active until mid-1954, but Smith continued research informally until his death in 1962. Smith concluded that UFOs were likely extraterrestrial in origin and operated by manipulating magnetism.

History ðŸ”—

The project began after Smith requested permission to use Department of Transport facilities to study UFOs. Approved on December 2, 1950, the project aimed to collect data on UFOs and apply it to practical engineering and technology, specifically geomagnetism and the possibility of using Earth’s magnetic field for propulsion. The project involved DOT facilities and assistance from the Defence Research Board (DRB) and the National Research Council. In June 1952, Smith issued a preliminary report suggesting UFOs came from intelligent, extraterrestrial sources and manipulated magnetism for flight. A 1953 report reiterated these conclusions. In April 1952, the Canadian government also established Project Second Storey, a parallel UFO research project involving Smith, consisting of scientists and military officers who met to consider the UFO question and recommend government action.

Smith also believed UFOs were linked to psychic phenomena and claimed to be in telepathic contact with extraterrestrial beings. He wrote articles for Topside, the publication of the Ottawa New Sciences Club, outlining the philosophy of the “Space Brothers” with whom he claimed to be in contact. These articles were later published posthumously in 1969 as The Boys from Topside.

Shirley’s Bay ðŸ”—

In October 1952, Smith established an observatory at Shirley’s Bay outside Ottawa to study UFO sightings, believing they emitted measurable physical characteristics. Project Magnet investigated several sighting reports, but the project was shut down in 1954. Smith continued to use the Shirley’s Bay facilities with his own funding until his death in 1962.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Magnet_(UFO)

item.title: Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law
item.description:
Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law ðŸ”—

This document details the Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law, a set of regulations enacted by NASA in 1969 to protect Earth from potential contamination by extraterrestrial organisms. The law was in effect from 1969 to 1977.

Regulations ðŸ”—

This section defines the core purpose of the Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law (14 CFR 1211). It highlights NASA’s responsibility and authority to prevent harmful contamination of Earth from returning space missions. The regulations were implemented before the Apollo 11 mission and provided the legal basis for quarantining astronauts. It defines “extraterrestrially exposed” as anything that has come into contact with or proximity to a celestial body or something that has been in contact with a celestial body.

Quarantining ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the practical application of the Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law, specifically the quarantine of astronauts returning from lunar missions. It mentions that the quarantines were implemented due to the possibility of unknown lunar organisms endangering life on Earth. The Apollo 11 astronauts were quarantined for 21 days after their return from the Moon. NASA filed notices establishing quarantine periods in the Federal Register for Apollo 11, 12, 13, and 14.

Termination ðŸ”—

This section details the end of the Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law’s enforcement and its eventual removal from the Code of Federal Regulations. After the Apollo 14 mission, NASA stopped enforcing the regulation due to analysis concluding there was no hazard to man, animals, or plants in the lunar material. Dr. George M. Low, NASA’s acting administrator, announced this decision. The rule was revoked in 1977 and formally removed from the Code of Federal Regulations in 1991.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the “Planetary protection” article, which is related to the prevention of interplanetary biological contamination.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources used in the article, including citations from the Code of Federal Regulations, news articles, and NASA documents.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the full text of the Extra-Terrestrial Exposure Law as published in the Federal Register.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra-Terrestrial_Exposure_Law
